questions.text: In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) waveform, which of the following statements accurately describes the "c wave"?

options.label: A
options.text: The "c wave" is caused by atrial systole

options.label: B
options.text: The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction

options.label: C
options.text: The "c wave" corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria

options.label: D
options.text: The "c wave" is influenced by the fluctuations in venous pressure caused by respiration

questions.correct_answer: B. The "c wave" arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction
questions.explanation:
a wave
  • Caused by atrial systole. (Option A ruled out)
  • Atrial contraction results in a temporary halt in venous inflow.
  • Some blood flows back into the veins, causing a rise in venous pressure.

c wave
  • Arises from the increase in atrial pressure during isovolumetric ventricular contraction. (Option B)
  • Pressure is transmitted through the closed and bulging tricuspid valve.

x descent
  • Ventricular systole pulls the tricuspid valve down

v wave
  • Corresponds to the rise in atrial pressure as blood fills the atria. (Option C ruled out)
  • Occurs during diastole while the tricuspid valve is still closed.

y descent
  • Opening of tricuspid valve causing emptying of right atrium into ventricle

questions.text: Which of the following accurately describes the differentiation pathway of hematopoietic stem cells (HSCs) in the production of granulocytes?

options.label: A
options.text: HSCs differentiate directly into granulocytes without intermediate stages.

options.label: B
options.text: HSCs differentiate into common lymphoid progenitors, which then produce granulocytes.

options.label: C
options.text: HSCs differentiate into common myeloid progenitors, which then give rise to granulocyte-monocyte progenitors.

options.label: D
options.text: HSCs differentiate into megakaryocyte-erythroid progenitors, which then produce granulocytes.

questions.correct_answer: C. HSCs differentiate into common myeloid progenitors, which then give rise to granulocyte-monocyte progenitors.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe chest pain and shortness of breath. His blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg, heart rate is 110 bpm, and has cold, clammy skin and elevated JVP. ECG shows ST-segment elevations in lead II, III and aVF. The patient is also oliguric. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms and signs?

options.label: A
options.text: Myocardial infarction

options.label: B
options.text: Sepsis

options.label: C
options.text: Adrenal insufficiency

options.label: D
options.text: Cardiac tamponade

questions.explanation:
Types of shock

Pathophysiology

Causes

Cardiac output

Cardiogenic

(Option A)

Inadequate pumping of the heart due to myocardial function.
  • Acute myocardial infarction
  • Heart failure
  • Cardiac arrhythmias
  

↓

Hypovolemic

Decreased amount of fluid in the vascular system
  • Acute hemorrhage
  • Burn
  • Metabolic: adrenal insufficiency (Option C ruled out), diabetic ketoacidosis
  • Severe diarrhea or vomiting.

 

↓

Distributive

Sudden increase in the vascular compartment capacity due to acute marked vasodilation
  • Neurogenic shock
  • Anaphylactic shock
  • Septic shock (Option B ruled out)

 

↓

Obstructive

Obstruction to the ejection of blood from the ventricle
  • Cardiac tamponade (Option D ruled out)
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Cardiac tumor
  • Tension pneumothorax

 

↓

questions.text: Which physiological mechanism best describes the Frank-Starling law of the heart?

options.label: A
options.text: The heart's stroke volume decreases as myocardial fiber length increases.

options.label: B
options.text: The heart's stroke volume is regulated primarily by sympathetic nervous system stimulation.

options.label: C
options.text: The heart's stroke volume increases in response to increased end-diastolic volume due to the length-tension relationship of cardiac muscle fibers.

options.label: D
options.text: The heart's stroke volume remains unchanged regardless of changes in venous return, due to intrinsic pacemaker activity

questions.correct_answer: C. The heart's stroke volume increases in response to increased end-diastolic volume due to the length-tension relationship of cardiac muscle fibers.

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with heart failure is evaluated for changes in myocardial contractility. Which of the following statements best describes the impact of decreased contractility on the Frank-Starling curve?

options.label: A
options.text: Shifts the curve upward and to the left, resulting in a greater stroke volume at any given preload.

options.label: B
options.text: Shifts the curve downward, resulting in a decreased stroke volume at any given preload.

options.label: C
options.text: Does not affect the Frank-Starling curve but increases the heart rate.

options.label: D
options.text: Shifts the curve upward and to the right, resulting in a decreased stroke volume at any given preload.

questions.correct_answer: B. Shifts the curve downward, resulting in a decreased stroke volume at any given preload.
questions.explanation:
Aspect

Details

Positive Bowditch Effect

Seen in healthy hearts, related to SER Ca load alterations.

Negative Bowditch Effect

Pathological, due to diminished SERCA protein expression, hallmark of heart failure.

Clinical Significance

Shift from increasing heart rate to beta-blockers for improved cardiac function in heart failure.

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient undergoes a blood transfusion, which results in a significant increase in blood volume. Which of the following best describes the physiological response to activation of the Bainbridge reflex due to an increase in blood volume?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased heart rate and decreased contractility

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in heart rate

options.label: C
options.text: Decreased heart rate and increased contractility

options.label: D
options.text: No change in heart rate or contractility

questions.explanation:
Aspect

Intrinsic Regulation: Frank-Starling Mechanism

Extrinsic Regulation: Autonomic Nervous System

Additional Factors

Integration of Mechanisms

Mechanism

Increased stretching of cardiac muscle leads to stronger contractions.

Sympathetic: Increases heart rate and contractility. Parasympathetic: Decreases heart rate and minimally affects contractility.

Temperature changes impact cardiac contractility.

Combines intrinsic, neural, and environmental factors to regulate cardiac output.

Visual Representation

Ventricular function curves.

-

-

-

Effects

Balances cardiac output and venous return.

Sympathetic: Boosts cardiac output; Parasympathetic: Reduces cardiac output.

Moderate increase: Enhances contractility; Prolonged increase: Decreases contractility.

Adjusts cardiac output to meet metabolic demands.

Examples

-

Sympathetic: Exercise or stress; Parasympathetic: Resting states.

Moderate: Exercise; Prolonged: Extended high temperatures.

-

questions.text: According to the Fick principle, which of the following is essential for calculating cardiac output?

options.label: A
options.text: Measurement of the patient’s blood pressure before and after exercise

options.label: B
options.text: Determination of the oxygen uptake by the lungs and the arteriovenous oxygen content difference

options.label: C
options.text: Assessment of the patient’s heart rate and electrocardiographic findings

options.label: D
options.text: Injection of a contrast dye and measurement of its concentration in the blood over time

questions.correct_answer: B. Determination of the oxygen uptake by the lungs and the arteriovenous oxygen content difference
questions.explanation:
Method

Principle

Measurement Basis

Key Considerations

Fick Principle

Oxygen uptake and arteriovenous difference

Oxygen content in blood

Accurate in steady states

Indicator Dilution Method

Indicator concentration dilution

Injected dye or tracer

Requires precise indicator handling

Echocardiography

Ultrasound visualization and flow velocity

Stroke volume estimation

Non-invasive, real-time data

Thoracic Electrical Bioimpedance

Electrical impedance changes

Impedance fluctuations

Sensitive to external factors

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient undergoes cardiac evaluation, and the following values are obtained: end-diastolic volume (EDV) of 140 mL, and ejection fraction of 48%. Which of the following best describes the patient's cardiac parameters?

options.label: A
options.text: The patient's ejection fraction is below the normal range, indicating reduced ventricular function.

options.label: B
options.text: The stroke volume is higher than normal, suggesting improved cardiac output.

options.label: C
options.text: The cardiac output is higher than average due to the increased EDV.

options.label: D
options.text: The cardiac output can be calculated accurately from the given values alone.

questions.correct_answer: A. The patient's ejection fraction is below the normal range, indicating reduced ventricular function.
questions.explanation:
Parameter

Description

Typical Value

Cardiac Output

The total volume of blood pumped by the heart per minute, reflecting its ability to meet the body's oxygen and nutrient demands.

Varies with demand

Stroke Volume

The volume of blood ejected from each ventricle per heartbeat.

~70-90 mL at rest

End-Diastolic Volume (EDV)

Volume of blood in the ventricle at the end of diastole, just before contraction.

~130 mL at rest

Cardiac Index

Cardiac output adjusted for body size, expressed as liters per minute per square meter of body surface area, allowing for comparison across different body sizes.

~3.2 L/min/m²

Ejection Fraction

Percentage of EDV ejected with each heartbeat, reflecting ventricular function and efficiency.

50%-70%

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient is undergoing evaluation of cardiac function, and a pressure-volume (PV) loop of the left ventricle is analyzed. From the PV loop, the following measurements are obtained: end-diastolic volume (EDV) is 140 mL and end-systolic volume (ESV) is 60 mL. What is the ejection fraction (EF) for this patient, and how is it calculated?

options.label: A
options.text: 30%, calculated as (EDV - ESV)/EDV

options.label: B
options.text: 43%, calculated as (SV/EDV) * 100

options.label: C
options.text: 57%, calculated as (EDV - ESV)/EDV

options.label: D
options.text: 57%, calculated as (SV/EDV) * 100

questions.explanation:
Parameter

Description

Formula

Normal Value

Stroke Volume (SV)

Volume of blood ejected from the left ventricle with each heartbeat.

SV = EDV - ESV

-

Ejection Fraction (EF)

Percentage of the end-diastolic volume ejected with each heartbeat.

EF = (SV/EDV) x 100%

~65%

questions.text: What is the duration of the cardiac cycle for a heart rate of 180 beats per minute?

options.label: A
options.text: 0.5 seconds

options.label: B
options.text: 0.75 seconds

options.label: C
options.text: 0.33 seconds

options.label: D
options.text: 0.66 seconds

questions.explanation:
Phase

Sub-Phase

Key Events

Systole

Isovolumetric Contraction
  • Ventricles begin to contract
  • Ranges from closure of AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) till opening of semilunar valves.
  • First heart sound appears.
  • No blood volume change in ventricles
 

Ventricular Ejection
  • Has 2 phases- Rapid ejection phase and Reduced ejection phase.
  • Ventricular pressure exceeds aortic and pulmonary pressure
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves open
  • Blood ejected into aorta and pulmonary artery
  • Ventricular volume decreases
  • Ends with the closure of the aortic valve.

Diastole

Isovolumetric Relaxation
  • Ventricles relax
  • Ventricular pressure drops
  • Aortic and pulmonary valves close
  • No blood volume change in ventricles
  • Second heart sounds appears.
  • Ends with the opening of AV valves.
 

Rapid Filling
  • AV valves (mitral and tricuspid) open
  • Blood flows rapidly from atria to ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases rapidly
  • Third heart sound appears.
 

Diastasis
  • Blood flow from atria to ventricles slows
  • No change in the atrial and ventricular pressure.
  • Ventricular volume increases slowly
 

Atrial Systole
  • Atria contract
  • Additional blood pushed into ventricles
  • Ventricular volume increases slightly
  • End-diastolic volume (EDV) reached
  • Fourth heart sound is produced.

questions.text: Which factor primarily contributes to an increased pulse pressure in the aortic pressure curve?

options.label: A
options.text: Decreased stroke volume

options.label: B
options.text: Increased arterial compliance

options.label: C
options.text: Increased stroke volume

options.label: D
options.text: Decreased heart rate

questions.explanation:
Phase

Description

Left Ventricle Contraction

Ventricular pressure increases until aortic valve opens

Period of Ejection

80-120 mmHg

Left ventricular pressure > aortic pressure; blood ejected

Isovolumic Relaxation

Aortic pressure forces blood back, closing aortic valve

Incisura

Notch on the curve due to aortic valve closure

Diastolic Decline 80mmHg diastolic

Aortic pressure declines as blood flows into systemic circulation

Factors Influencing Aortic Pressure

  • Stroke Volume
  • Arterial Compliance

Transmission of Pressure Pulses

  • Pressure Wave Propagation- generated by ventricular contraction travels through the arterial system
  • Dampening Effect- pulsations diminish in smaller arteries, becoming negligible in the capillaries.

Phase

Description

Left Ventricle Contraction

Ventricular pressure increases until aortic valve opens

Period of Ejection

Left ventricular pressure > aortic pressure; blood ejected

Isovolumic Relaxation

Aortic pressure forces blood back, closing aortic valve

Incisura

Notch on the curve due to aortic valve closure

Diastolic Decline

Aortic pressure declines as blood flows into systemic circulation

questions.text: A 30-year-old healthy volunteer undergoes invasive hemodynamic monitoring. At which point in the cardiac cycle is the pressure gradient between the left atrium and left ventricle greatest, and what event does this gradient trigger?

options.label: A
options.text: End of atrial systole; opening of mitral valve

options.label: B
options.text: Mid-ventricular systole; closure of aortic valve

options.label: C
options.text: Early diastole; rapid ventricular filling

options.label: D
options.text: End of isovolumic relaxation; opening of mitral valve

questions.correct_answer: D. End of isovolumic relaxation; opening of mitral valve

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with suspected heart failure undergoes a comprehensive cardiac evaluation. During auscultation, both S3 and S4 are heard. Regarding the correlation of these extra heart sounds with the ECG, which statement is correct?

options.label: A
options.text: S3 occurs during the P wave; S4 coincides with the QRS complex

options.label: B
options.text: S3 is heard after the T wave & before next P wave; S4 occurs immediately after the P wave

options.label: C
options.text: S3 coincides with the U wave; S4 is heard during the PR interval

options.label: D
options.text: S3 occurs during the ST segment; S4 is heard at the peak of the R wave

questions.correct_answer: B. S3 is heard after the T wave & before next P wave; S4 occurs immediately after the P wave
questions.explanation:
Phase

Heart Sound

Timing on ECG

Cause

Clinical Significance

Key Points

Early Diastole

S3

Early diastole, after T wave

Rapid ventricular filling

Normal in children and athletes; in adults may indicate heart failure
  • Rapid ventricular filling phase
  • AV valves open
  • Ventricles relax

Late Diastole

S4

Late diastole, just before P wave

Atrial contraction against a stiff ventricle

Always abnormal; may indicate hypertension, ischemia, or cardiomyopathy
  • Atrial systole
  • Completes ventricular filling
  • Precedes next ventricular systole

questions.text: During a cardiac examination, a 35-year-old patient's simultaneous ECG and phonocardiography are recorded. Which of the following statements most accurately describes the relationship between the second heart sound (S2) and the ECG?

options.label: A
options.text: S2 occurs at the peak of the T wave in all cardiac cycles

options.label: B
options.text: S2 is heard just before the T wave

options.label: C
options.text: S2 coincides with the onset of the U wave when present

options.label: D
options.text: S2 typically occurs at the end of T wave and the subsequent P wave

questions.correct_answer: D. S2 typically occurs at the end of T wave and the subsequent P wave
questions.explanation:
Phase

Heart Sound

Timing on ECG

Cause

Clinical Significance

Key Points

Systole

S2

At the end of the T-wave

Closure of aortic and pulmonic valves

Normal finding; Split S2 may indicate delayed pulmonic valve closure
  • Ventricular ejection ends
  • Marks beginning of diastole
  • Aortic valve closes

questions.text: Regarding the timing and correlation of the Phonocardiogram's first heart sound (S1) with the ECG, which of the following statements is CORRECT?

options.label: A
options.text: S1 occurs immediately after the P wave and coincides with atrial systole

options.label: B
options.text: S1 begins during the ST segment and ends before the T wave

options.label: C
options.text: S1 starts 0.02-0.04 seconds after the onset of the QRS complex

options.label: D
options.text: S1 is heard simultaneously with the peak of the R wave in all lead

questions.correct_answer: C. S1 starts 0.02-0.04 seconds after the onset of the QRS complex
questions.explanation:
Phase

Heart Sound

Timing on ECG

Cause

Clinical Significance

Key Points

Systole

S1

Just after QRS complex

Closure of mitral and tricuspid valves

Normal finding; Split S1 may indicate bundle branch block
  • Ventricular contraction begins
  • Isovolumetric contraction phase
  • Aortic valve opens

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient undergoes cardiac catheterization with simultaneous ECG recording. During the isovolumic relaxation phase, which combination of events is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: T wave ends; ventricular pressure falls below atrial pressure; mitral valve opens

options.label: B
options.text: U wave begins; ventricular pressure equals aortic pressure; all valves closed

options.label: C
options.text: P wave starts; ventricular volume increases; tricuspid valve opens

options.label: D
options.text: Second heart sound occurs; ventricular pressure drops rapidly; aortic valve closes

questions.correct_answer: D. Second heart sound occurs; ventricular pressure drops rapidly; aortic valve closes

questions.text: During the isovolumic contraction phase, which of the following combinations of events is most accurate?

options.label: A
options.text: Second heart sound occurs; ventricular pressure exceeds atrial pressure; aortic valve opens

options.label: B
options.text: QRS complex ends; ventricular pressure rises but remains below aortic pressure; all valves closed

options.label: C
options.text: T wave begins; ventricular volume decreases slightly; mitral valve closes

options.label: D
options.text: Second heart sound occurs; ventricular pressure equals aortic pressure; pulmonary valve closes

questions.correct_answer: B. QRS complex ends; ventricular pressure rises but remains below aortic pressure; all valves closed
